ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned ASL and Deaf culture
Deepened my ASL vocabulary and broadened my deaf culture knowledge.
ASL sentence structure, new vocab, and Deaf culture (including Deaf space, Deaf identity, and Black ASL)
I really liked this class, the teacher was amazing and very engaging.
I learned more about Deaf culture and ASL grammar.
I learned more about deaf culture, how to express more ideas in ASL, we studied stories and narratives, and greatly expanded our vocabularies.
I improved my ASL knowledge and feel more comfortable having conversations. I additionally have a better understanding of Deaf culture and history.
I learned about various aspects of deaf culture, as well as how to tell a story and communicate directions in sign language
More ASL techniques and vocabulary, for sure. But more than that, I really enjoyed the material in Deaf studies, particularly Black Deaf studies, that we got to discuss.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: great teacher, engaging class

Weaknesses: the homework doesn't exactly match up with what we are taught in class. Kind of seems like they are forcing Dawn Sign Press on us when I genuinely think that there are much better alternatives to homework assignments. I also thing we need to review content more often in class. Julia would review the same new signs for practically a week, but Francis tended to teach us a sign and then not return to it later in the week. Also, please make quizzes by the professor for the students they have. I had Francis, but when I would have to answer questions that Andrew signed, I felt so lost.

Engaging teaching style with a lot of flexibility and variation.

The games are fun but I would say it is enough with 1-2 games per week, not every day. More practice in pairs to make sure vocabulary etc sticks.

Strengths: curriculum, format of the course, community-building, service project
Weaknesses: communication about exams

The course is structured pretty well, but we played too many games in class. I felt like our time would have been better used with repetitive practice of vocabulary and ASL conversations between students.

Frances is an incredible teacher. I can't say enough good things about her. She was in a good mood for every class, and you could tell she was super enthusiastic to be teaching us. She was encouraging, and didn't ever make you feel bad about being lost or confused. She was incredibly kind and understanding. One time I submitted a quiz late because I had a lot going on, and she totally understood and didn't take points away because of it. I was excited to go to class every day, and every day felt like a game and never like work. She is exactly what you want a Yale teacher to be.
I wish there was maybe more service project guidance.

Probably the most fun and useful language offered at Yale. I loved that we not only got to practice ASL but also engage with Deaf studies. One weakness was that feedback on expressive assignments came a bit late.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! You learn a ton, and it's pretty low stress.
Yes.
Yes! You'll learn a lot and form a great community (and fulfill your language requirement).
Yes!!
YES!!
Yes! ASL is a language that more people should know, and the class itself is very fun.
Absolutely. Professor Conlin is incredible, and you will be excited to go to class every day.
Yes! I love ASL and all of the professors are great
Yes! The ASL program at Yale is fantastic.
